steps.title: Take higher doses of ibuprofen to halt or delay your period.
steps.content: Take higher doses of ibuprofen to halt or delay your period. Some people have luck delaying a period by taking 800 milligrams of ibuprofen every 6 hours. Keep in mind, though, that this dose is higher than what's recommended on over-the-counter bottles of ibuprofen, so you should talk to your doctor before attempting this method. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Another option is taking 500 milligrams of naproxen 3 times a day.

steps.title: Try having sex during your period.
steps.content: Try having sex during your period. Having sex with a partner or on your own may shorten your period. When you orgasm, it may cause the lining of your uterus to shed more quickly, as your vagina muscles contract. [2] X Research source While this doesn't work for everyone, it may be helpful. Plus, it can help in other ways, such as reducing painful cramps. If you want to stop your period for a short time while you're having sex, try a menstrual disc. This fits up near your uterus and makes sex possible without the mess.

steps.title: See an acupuncturist for longer periods.
steps.content: See an acupuncturist for longer periods. If you are having continuous bleeding or heavy bleeding, also known as menorrhagia, acupuncture may help. Some people find seeing an acupuncturist relieves their symptoms or shortens their periods. [3] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Ask your doctor for a recommendation for an acupuncturist in your area. If your doctor doesn't know one, try searching online for one with good reviews. Acupuncture involves the professional placing tiny needles at different pressure points on your body. Most people find the needles don't hurt because they are so small.

steps.title: Slow down heavy or long periods with chasteberry.
steps.content: Slow down heavy or long periods with chasteberry. This supplement is also known as chaste tree. Try taking 15 drops of liquid extract once a day. You can add it to tea or another liquid to make it more palatable. [4] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source Some people with heavy periods find this lessens the length of their period.

steps.title: Ask your doctor about birth control to skip periods.
steps.content: Ask your doctor about birth control to skip periods. Birth control can help regulate your periods, but it can also help you skip a single cycle or stop having periods altogether. In most birth control packs, you have 21 active pills and 7 sugar pills. To skip a single cycle, don't take the 7 sugar pills and start your next pack of pills instead. Typically, the sugar pills are a different color, such as being white when the rest of the pills are yellow. [5] X Trustworthy Source National Health Service (UK) Public healthcare system of the UK Go to source Always talk to your doctor to determine if this is a safe choice for you. You can also stop having periods altogether by taking continuous birth control, meaning you get the kind that doesn't have placebos or you skip your placebos every month. [6] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source An intrauterine device (IUD) may also provide long-term period relief. Hormonal IUDs tend to lighten your periods over time, and they may completely stop them within a year. They deliver a low does of hormones over time, and you can leave them in for up to 5 years. [7] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Your gynecologist can insert an IUD for you. It's a small device that fits into your uterus. After insertion, you typically won't feel it.

steps.title: Watch for symptoms of excessively heavy bleeding.
steps.content: Watch for symptoms of excessively heavy bleeding. Many people have heavy cycles, but it becomes excessive if you bleed through a pad or tampon in an hour and do so for several hours in a row. Another symptom of excessive bleeding is having to use more than one type of hygiene product, such as using a tampon and pad together. [8] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Other symptoms of excessive flow include having to wake up to change your pad or tampon at night and not being able to do normal activities because your period is so heavy. You may also see bigger blood clots in your pads, about the size of a quarter. See your healthcare provider if you experience frequent blood clots. [9] X Expert Source Rebecca Levy-Gantt, MPT, DO Board Certified Obstetrician & Gynecologist Expert Interview. 3 April 2020.

steps.title: Look for periods longer than a week.
steps.content: Look for periods longer than a week. A typical period lasts between 3 and 7 days. If yours is lasting longer than a week, that's considered excessive. If you are having very long periods or you don't have breaks between periods, you need to see a doctor. [10] X Trustworthy Source Mayo Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you're bleeding heavily for many days in a row, you may start to notice signs of anemia, including extreme tiredness and shortness of breath.

steps.title: See your gynecologist if you're experiencing symptoms of heavy or extended cycles.
steps.content: See your gynecologist if you're experiencing symptoms of heavy or extended cycles. Your doctor will ask you about the symptoms you're experiencing. They'll also discuss your medical history with you so come prepared. [11] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source It can help to track how many pads or tampons you're using on your period. That gives your doctor an idea of how much you're bleeding.

steps.title: Expect a physical exam.
steps.content: Expect a physical exam. If you're having symptoms of heavy bleeding, your doctor is going to want to do a pelvic exam. During the exam, you'll be asked to remove your clothes and get up on an exam table. You will need to spread your legs so your doctor can examine your vaginal area. [12] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source The doctor will insert a speculum in your vagina. This might be uncomfortable, but it shouldn't be too painful. The doctor will also do a pap smear, where they take a small sampling of cells from your uterus. Your doctor may also take a small tissue sample for a biopsy. If possible, your doctor may want to wait until the bleeding has stopped to have this exam.

steps.title: Be ready for blood tests, ultrasounds, and other diagnostic tests.
steps.content: Be ready for blood tests, ultrasounds, and other diagnostic tests. Diagnostic tests will help your doctor determine a diagnosis and proper treatment for you. For a blood test, a technician will draw blood from your arm and then send it off to be tested. For an ultrasound, a medical professional will pass an electronic wand over your abdomen and uterus area to see what's going on inside. [13] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source

steps.title: Discuss treatments with your doctor.
steps.content: Discuss treatments with your doctor. The treatment will depend on your diagnosis. If nothing else is wrong, your doctor may just recommend hormone treatments, such as birth control. Alternatively, your doctor may suggest an NSAID like ibuprofen for cramps, as well as iron supplements if you're anemic. [14] X Trustworthy Source Johns Hopkins Medicine Official resource database of the world-leading Johns Hopkins Hospital Go to source For other issues, such as problems with your uterine lining, you may need a surgical procedure. For instance, you may need the lining of your uterus removed or even a hysterectomy, where your uterus is removed completely.
